lead_paragraph: Why are we so concerned with bacteria related to the five-second rule? Other surfaces are far more dangerous.

byline.contributor: Aaron E. Carroll is a professor of pediatrics at Indiana University School of Medicine who blogs on health research and policy at The Incidental Economist and makes videos at Healthcare Triage. Follow him on Twitter at @aaronecarroll.

headline.print_headline: I’m a Doctor. If I Drop Food on the Floor, I’ll Still Eat It.
headline.main: I’m a Doctor. If I Drop Food on the Kitchen Floor, I Still Eat It.

snippet: Why are we so concerned with bacteria related to the five-second rule? Other surfaces are far more dangerous....
abstract: The Upshot; number of studies have tested validity of so-called five-second rule, which states that food is safe to eat if it has only touched floor for five seconds; reality is that all household surfaces offer potentially hazardous array of bacteria, and consumers should make informed judgment based on known cleanliness of any surface rather than on arbitrary rule about contact time.
